title: Dock4
text:
Dock4, (Dedicator of cytokinesis 4) also known as DOCK4, is a large (~190 kDa) <a href="protein">protein</a> involved in <a href="intracellular">intracellular</a> <a href="cell%20signalling">signalling networks</a>. It is a member of the DOCK-B subfamily of the <a href="DOCK%20%28protein%29">DOCK</a> family of <a href="guanine%20nucleotide%20exchange%20factor">guanine nucleotide exchange factor</a>s (GEFs) which function as activators of small <a href="G%20protein">G protein</a>s. Dock4 activates the small G proteins <a href="Rac%20%28GTPase%29">Rac</a> and <a href="Rap%20GTP-binding%20protein">Rap1</a>.
Discovery.
Dock4 was discovered as a <a href="gene%20product">gene product</a> which was disrupted during <a href="tumour">tumour</a> progression in a murine cancer model-derived <a href="osteosarcoma">osteosarcoma</a> cell line. Subsequent <a href="Northern%20blot">Northern blot</a> analysis revealed high levels of Dock4 <a href="Gene%20expression">expression</a> in <a href="skeletal%20muscle">skeletal muscle</a>, <a href="prostate">prostate</a> and <a href="ovary">ovary</a> as well as lower levels in the <a href="heart">heart</a>, <a href="placenta">placenta</a> and <a href="Colon%20%28anatomy%29">colon</a>. A separate study has reported expression of a Dock4 <a href="Alternative%20splicing">splice variant</a> (<a href="Dock4-Ex49">Dock4-Ex49</a>) in the brain, <a href="inner%20ear">inner ear</a> and eye.
Structure and function.
Dock4 is part of a large class of proteins (GEFs) which contribute to cellular signalling events by activating small G proteins. In their resting state G proteins are bound to <a href="Guanosine%20diphosphate">Guanosine diphosphate</a> (GDP) and their activation requires the dissociation of GDP and binding of <a href="guanosine%20triphosphate">guanosine triphosphate</a> (GTP). GEFs activate G proteins by promoting this nucleotide exchange.
The domain arrangement of Dock4 is largely equivalent to that of <a href="Dock180">Dock180</a> (the archetypal member of the <a href="DOCK%20%28protein%29">DOCK</a> family) and other DOCK-A/B family members (35% <a href="Sequence%20alignment">sequence identity</a> with Dock180, 39% with <a href="Dock2">Dock2</a> and 54% with <a href="Dock3">Dock3</a>). Dock4, however, contains a unique set of <a href="Structural%20motif">motifs</a> at its <a href="proline">proline</a>-rich <a href="C-terminus">C-terminus</a> which include a <a href="Src%20%28gene%29">Src</a>-binding site that is shared with <a href="CED-5">CED-5</a>, the "<a href="Caenorhabditis%20elegans">C. elegans</a>" <a href="ortholog">ortholog</a> of mammalian DOCK proteins. Dock4 also contains a <a href="DHR2%20domain">DHR2 domain</a> (also known as Docker2 or CZH2) which is conserved among DOCK family proteins and mediates GEF-dependent functions, and a <a href="DHR1%20domain">DHR1 domain</a> (CZH1/Docker1) which has been shown to bind <a href="Phosphatidylinositol%20%283%2C4%2C5%29-trisphosphate">PtdIns(3,4,5)P3</a>, an important step in recruitment to the <a href="plasma%20membrane">plasma membrane</a>.
Regulation of Dock4 activity.
DOCK family proteins are inefficient at promoting nucleotide exchange on their own since they appear to adopt an autoinhibitory <a href="Protein%20folding">conformation</a> in their resting state. The <a href="Signal%20transducing%20adaptor%20protein">adaptor protein</a> <a href="ELMO%20%28protein%29">ELMO</a> has been shown to bind DOCK proteins and induce a conformational change which relieves the inhibition and allows G proteins access to the DHR2 domain. Binding to ELMO requires the atypical <a href="PH%20domain">PH domain</a> of ELMO and also involves an interaction between the <a href="N-terminal">N-terminal</a> <a href="SH3%20domain">SH3 domain</a> of DOCK and a proline-rich motif at the ELMO C-terminus. ELMO also binds the activated form of the small G protein <a href="RhoG">RhoG</a> and this has been shown to promote DOCK-dependent signalling by helping recruit the ELMO-DOCK <a href="protein%20complex">complex</a> to areas of high <a href="substrate%20%28biochemistry%29">substrate</a> availability (usually the plasma membrane). The C-terminus of DOCK proteins interacts with another adaptor protein, <a href="CRK%20%28gene%29">Crk</a>. Dock4 undergoes RhoG/ELMO-dependent recruitment to the plasma membrane and promotes <a href="cell%20migration">migration</a> in <a href="fibroblasts">fibroblasts</a>. In rat <a href="hippocampus">hippocampal</a> <a href="neurone">neurone</a>s Dock4 forms a trimeric complex with <a href="ELMO2">ELMO2</a> and <a href="CrkII">CrkII</a> which is required for the normal development of <a href="dendrite">dendrite</a>s. More recently, a role has been described for Dock4 as part of the <a href="Wnt%20signalling%20pathway">Wnt signalling pathway</a> which regulates <a href="cell%20proliferation">cell proliferation</a> and migration. In this system Dock4 was reported to undergo <a href="phosphorylation">phosphorylation</a> by <a href="Glycogen%20synthase%20kinase%203">Glycogen synthase kinase 3</a> (GSK-3) which stimulated an increase in Dock4 GEF activity.
Signalling downstream of Dock4.
DOCK family proteins contribute to cell signalling by activating G proteins of the Rho family, such as Rac and <a href="Cdc42">Cdc42</a>. Dock4 has also been shown to activate Rap1, a feature not reported in any of the other DOCK family proteins to date. Dock4 dependent Rac activation regulates reorganisation of the <a href="cytoskeleton">cytoskeleton</a> and leads to the formation of membrane protrusions (e.g. <a href="lamellipodia">lamellipodia</a>) which are a crucial step in neuronal development and cell migration. The effect of Dock4 on the Wnt pathway appears to be mediated through Rac activation as well as through GEF-independent associations with components of the "<a href="Beta-catenin">β-catenin</a> degradation complex".
Dock4 in cancer.
Mutations in Dock4 have been described in a number of cancers. The exact mechanism and extent to which it regulates cancer-associated signalling pathways is poorly understood thus far although a mutation in Dock4 which affects its GEF specificity has been reported to promote detachment and invasion of cancer cells.
